study.title: Interpreting Agent Behavior in a Treasure Game

consent.title: Welcome to the Treasure Game Study
content: We are conducting an experiment about how people interpret other agents' behavior in a game. Your answers will be used to inform computer science and cognitive science research.
This experiment should take about 15-18 minutes.
You will be compensated for your time at the end of the study.
Your participation is completely voluntary. You can agree to take part and later change your mind. Your decision will not be held against you.

content.value:
Welcome!

In this experiment, you will watch 16 short animations of a player in a treasure game. Your task will be to infer the player's goals from their actions.

You're watching a player in a treasure game.

The rules of the game are as follows:
  • There are 4 kinds of gems on the map:
  • The game is played on a grid of black and white squares.
  • The player can move only on the white squares.
  • The player has a full view of the map at all times.
  • The player's objective is to collect exactly one of the gems.
  • Keys are used to unlock doors of the same color (e.g. red keys unlock red doors ).
  • Each key can only be used once. Keys disappear after use.
Your task is to rate how likely each possible gem is to be the player's goal based on the actions you see them taking.

For each possible gem on the map, you will rate how likely it is to be the player's goal using a slider.

  • Slide to the right if you think the gem is very likely to be their goal
  • Slide to the middle if you're unsure
  • Slide to the left if you think the gem is unlikely to be their goal
Please move each slider to reflect your assessment. You must move all sliders to proceed.

config.commentary: This is a practice scenario. Watch the animation and then rate the player's goals.
config.question: For each gem, use the slider to indicate how likely you think it is to be the player's goal.

feedback.title: Feedback
feedback.content: In this scenario, the player went for the red key to open the red door, making Gem A the likely goal. Gem C was also possible, as the player could have used the blue key. Gem B was unlikely because the player moved away from the yellow key needed to access it.

content.question: What is your task in this experiment?
options: Rate how likely different gems are to be the player's goal using sliders.
Control the player to help them collect gems.
Type descriptions of what the player is thinking.

content.question: How do you indicate that a gem is very likely to be the player's goal?
options: Move the slider toward the right (higher values).
Move the slider toward the left (lower values).
Leave the slider in the middle position.

content.question: What do the middle positions (50) on the sliders represent?
options: You're certain the gem is the player's goal.
You're uncertain about whether the gem is the player's goal.
You're certain the gem is not the player's goal.
